headline: Pennsylvania Democratic Party Senate candidates set to debate Thursday
author: George Stockburger
sentences:
The Debate

HARRISBURG, Pa. (WHTM) — The May 17 primary election for the open Pennsylvania seat in the United States Senate is just a few short weeks away and three Democratic primary candidates, hoping to get Pennsylvanian’s votes, will debate for one hour on Thursday, April 21 at 8 p.m. on abc27.

While Kenyatta has received the least among the three candidates debating Thursday night, he has received both donations and verbal support from multiple celebrities including Halle Berry, Amy Schumer, Robin Thicke Tasha Smith, and Wanda Skyes, during his campaign run.

In an even more recent poll conducted by Franklin & Marshall, while nearly half the 785 registered voters surveyed between March 30 and April 10 said they will vote for a Republican congressional candidate, Fetterman still led the Democratic party.

On his campaign website, Fetterman says that the criminal justice system needs a significant overhaul, plus, he supports legalizing the recreational use of marijuana, a $15 minimum wage in the state, and that health care is a fundamental right.

On his campaign website, Lamb says he supports raising the minimum wage to $15, protecting and strengthening the Affordable Care Act, recommitting to public education, and reinventing clemency and the pardon process in Pennsylvania.

Conor Lamb, Western Pennsylvania Congressman (D-17)
The only other candidate to receive a double-digit percentage of voters in the WHTM/Emerson College Polling/The Hill poll is Western Pennsylvania Congressman Lamb (D-17).
The candidates will be asked for their views on the infrastructure, the economy, foreign policy, the legalization of recreational marijuana use, and other important topics impacting Pennsylvania.
The debate will both air and live-stream in 10 markets across Pennsylvania, New York, Ohio, and Maryland, reaching 9.8 million TV and streaming households in every county of the Keystone State.
As reported by the Associated Press last week, Fetterman has been on the defensive in recent weeks after Lamb, Kenyatta, and a super PAC supporting Lamb accused Fetterman of being extreme.
Another high point in Kenyatta’s campaign: he was the first to receive the required number of signatures just three days after the petitioning window opened for the Senate candidates.
A WHTM/Emerson College Polling/The Hill poll conducted from March 26 to 28, interviewing 508 Democrats, showed Fetterman receiving 33.4%, a significant lead over the other candidates.

Malcolm Kenyatta, Philadelphia State Representative (D-181)
Coming in third in both of the previously mentioned polls is State Representative Malcolm Kenyatta (D-181).
WHTM abc27 News anchor and Capitol Bureau Reporter Dennis Owens and WPXI Anchor Lisa Sylvester will co-moderate the debate from the abc27 studio in Harrisburg.

In a breakdown by age, Fetterman led in all age ranges and a significant number of white voters supported him over any other candidate.

The gap between Fetterman and Kenyatta did shrink, however, in African-American voters with Fetterman leading only by 1.2% more.
In the Democratic party, Lamb also has the second most Q1 contributions in the first three months of 2022, with $1,759,096.46.
He collected signatures from seven different counties to be the first official candidate added to the May 17 primary ballot.
The percentage of voters committed to voting for Lamb in the primary increased in the Franklin & Marshall poll.
